title: Twitter notification text messages cut off

thread.text:
I never had this problem with my old phone (which was an iphone), but I get twitter notifications as text messages and for some reason, ever since I switched to the Galaxy S7 Active a lot of my text messages seem to get cut off and end with an ellipsis (...)
It's very frustrating because often times if is in the middle of a link, but it actually puts the ellipsis into the link so when I click on it I can't load the page.
I'm assuming there is a character limit or something going on, so I was wondering if anyone knew how I could turn that off on the default messaging app? or if not is there a decent messaging app that will allow the whole text to come through? I find it very odd that this never was an issue on my old phone, but somehow it is with this one.

replies.text: oh my gosh i've been suffering through this and have been confounded by the lack of a discussion or solution, did you ever figure out a way to receive full texts from twitter instead of only cut off ones?? it's beyond frustrating.

thread.text: I have a Samsung galaxy S7active. I use the default app for texts. I did an update today and can no longer add a background to my text conversations. Is there a new way to get to that setting? I hate the plain white.
Id also like to know how lol
I'd like to know too. What could possibly be the point of removing the option. I'm disliking samsung more everyday.

if anyone finds a way please share. 
for time being using Textra
In the newest update that feature was removed. The note 8, s8 series and s9 series are all the same way now. Can't be done without a new update.

I am now using stock Samsung Messages App with a theme called "Mattblack".
This allows most of all screens to be blacked out including messages screen :-)

See multiple threads...

title: S7 Active Updated Software - Unlisted baseband version

thread.text:
So my phone updated today and afterward it was running really smooth, fast, looked a little different and overall improved. So I thought I would research the update just to see if there were any cool changes that I hadn't already noticed. So I looked up the baseband version. All that came up was a weird middle eastern looking website. I have never done anything to my phone other than regular use and update when prompted; never tried to root or any of this other stuff because it is way over my head. The site seemed to be integrated toward doing that sort of thing to your phone. It was in terrible pieces of English, so I didn't get much from it. So the phone is a S7 active, baseband version is g891aucu2brb5. According to Samsung and At&t, the latest software baseband version for this phone should be G891AUCS2BRA7. Again, I know very little about technical stuff like this, but I assume this is not a good thing. The baseband code appears to be "newer" than the phone should have? 
So I have no idea what this all means, if anything? Any help please

When you go to the battery section all the items already selective if you go to Safe hour. Other than that I see no other major changes. I really would like to change the colors in the text messaging app as I use a dark theme and now it does not work well

title: New Software update.....how to fix it..

thread.text:
New software update...March 15th 2018..
so far 3 things happen on my end are wi fi calling notifications and message screen / format and smiley / sticker icon.
I get annoying wi fi notification pop up every 30 minutes... I turn off via APPs setting, etc..no worky... contact AT&T........ AT&T turn it off for me.. so far problem solved.
My message screen is funky... I cannot insert background picture, changes text color or bubbles... AT&T said it is Samsung end... 
How can I go back to previous message format or change existing color?
As for smiley / sticker icon... I don't really care for it... I am letting it go but would like to have background picture back.
MESSAGE VERSION 5.0.10.9
Same problem here. I use my phone primarily at night and the white background is terrible!!

1. AT&T took care of.
2. You can't with the Samsung app, you'll have to find an SMS app that allows it, then make that your default SMS app. (If you back up your apps, you can uninstall the current one and install the older one.)
3. That's the new RCS format, the way Google has it implemented. Since it's a brand new protocol (most carriers don't even support it yet), either install another SMS app, or wait it out. (It's not that bad - back in 2003, we couldn't send MMS between carriers. We had to wait that out too. Now no one would believe it.)
Textra for #2

title: Active button doesn't work when screen has been locked.

thread.text:
Hi all,
This issue is driving me crazy. For some reason, once I turn off the screen by pressing the power button and then wait a little bit, if I press the Active button to bring up any chosen app, it doesn't do anything. This morning, for no reason, it worked for a few hours, but then the same problem. Other times, the screen comes up but it asks me for my fingerprint. Has anybody had these issues?
I asked this question in the XDA forums but only one person answered and it worked for him. But seems it's so random, that I would like to get more input from you guys to see if there is something wrong with my phone.
This is my configuration and how to test it:
1. Be sure that when you click the Active button it brings up an app.
2. Go to "Lock screen and security" and click on "Screen lock type". Select a fingerprint and a secondary locking mode (Pattern, PIN or password)
3. Go to "Secure lock settings" and click on "Secured lock time". Select the first option "Instantly with the power key or..."
4. Press the Home button and then the Power key to turn it off.
5. Wait a little bit. Sometimes it could be seconds or up to 10 minutes.
6. Press the Active button. Does it do anything?
Thanks so much
UPDATE: It seems that if you have the app "Activity Zone" configured for the active button, it usually works more often. Could you guys try with a different app?
Never mind. Since nobody can't spend a few minutes trying this, I went to an AT&T store to check this myself.

I have the S6A and the active button works the same way. If you have a lock on your phone, the active button will bring up the app, but in the background. Once you enter your pass code (whichever option that may be such as swipe, PIN, etc), the app should appear and open. Unfortunately, even with the "active key on lock screen" option set to ON, the app will not bypass the security lock. I wish the phone would allow you to go into the desired app, bypassing the lock screen if the "active key on lock screen" option was set to ON, but it doesn't unfortunately.

replies.text:
Thanks for your reply. I'm a developer so I have also be doing some testing about the active key. The Active key does bring the app back on, but only if it's doing something in the background, I assume if it has a service running, for example, getting the current location. If that's the case, it will come up, no matter how long the screen has been turned off. However, on the other hand, if the app that you want to bring up is the calculator, it will never do anything at all.
Also, it will ask you for a password every time, unless that app has the option to disable the lock screen (I think also needs to be in in the foreground but I haven't tested that), such as Google Maps or the Activity Zone. Not many apps do that. Even the activity zone I think it goes to a sleep state sometimes, and it won't bring it up at all.

thread.text:

It would be really convenient to just grab phone from pocket and press one button to turn torch on and off. (Maybe on a double press so it wont acitvate in the pocket). Going to activity zone and turn it on there consumes just much more time and ease of use if one uses it frequently

Is there a torch app that you can use for that or you have to automate is with some app?
Thanks for the info in advance!

title: Location Services turning on on it's own!

thread.text: I've notices on my Active that the Location Services are turned on, and I did not do it, nor have I given any app permission to turn it on. What or Why is it doing it on it's own?
The NSA is keeping track of you.

If your Location Services are off, and you use an app that needs them, it will prompt you to turn them on (perhaps saying that it wants to improve accuracy). Is it possible that you accepted one of these prompts quickly while using the app, without being fully aware of what it was asking?
Figured it was a glitch as I'm pretty good about understanding the android screens. But time will tell as I keep an eye on it.
It can happen to any of us. I've done it from time to time.

Well it did it again. This time the phone did an auto update to the FB App (I don't even use it) overnight on it's own. I noticed the Location Service was on, swiped down and over, then while I was looking at it it turned it self back off. Strange.
Do you mean that you saw the little Location icon (the map pushpin) appear in the status bar, and then disappear?

Yes, when I woke the phone up it was there, I swiped down to show the setting menu, and then over to show the toggle for the GPS Location Services, and it was Blue, I looked at it for a moment, and then it turned gray, turned it self off.
I also noticed while hanging up from a phone call today it was on, and before I could swipe down it turned off again.
You may have already done this already, but go to Settings>Location, tap More, and look for an option to Improve Accuracy. Make sure that's turned off.

On the s7 Active by AT&T the Setting Menus are different than they were on the s6 I had on VZW, so that menu path doesn't exist. But under Personal>Privacy ans safety>Location Improved Accuracy isn't black (it's gray) and is shows Recent Location Request were from: Google Play Services. IMS Service & Maps. Also Google Location History off and empty.
Does this happen in Safe Mode? https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-28008. This can at least narrow it down to a system/preinstalled app or a 3rd party app you installed.
Not sure it's repeatable enough to know what's triggering it to see if it does happen in safe mode. Once I find a common action/time I'll give that a try,

I've still not determined what's causing the problem, but today while I was in Google Maps looking up an address, all of a sudden the map jumped and showed my location on the map! I looked at the top and locations services icon was on, and just a suddenly as it turned it self on, it turned off and my location on the may was gone!
So the Icon popping up in the top bar isn't just an icon issue, the GPS is turning it self on and then back off!
(The only applications with recent Location Services Access per the Settings is Google Play and Google Maps).
Further reading and investigating makes it look clear to me that it's Google Play. So no other Active users are experiencing this?
I've never seen it happen but I'll try to keep an eye on it for a while!
When I rebooted the phone I noticed it came on and then went back off just after completing the boot. Google Play Services and Maps still show as the only recent location request.
With the last update the F'ing phone is at it again, and not displaying the little push pin icon at the top when it is on!
That is strange - mine is there! As a matter of fact, I'm using it tomorrow to get into Boston and the Push Pin is showing right now and I got that Upgrade the other night too! ???
Yea, this is still happening on my phone. Randomly turns on while battery saving mode is selected.

Yep, mine is still doing it, and it just now did it while checking gMail. I've also had problems in the past week where the phone keeps nagging me to turn it on as apps can't access my location and i might not be able to find my phone if lost. I've not added any new apps, and it's been a week since any apps.phone updates applied.

I haven't had any "requests" to turn it on but the Icon does pop up "by itself" and then disappear "by itself" in the taskbar randomly, even though I also am running Power Saving Mode. It is rather strange - unfortunately, I don't know if it ever did that before the Nougat Upgrade or not so I can't say if that's the issue! I am still getting really great battery performance so it doesn't bother me but I can see where it is an underlying annoyance to others! I've just gotten too old and easy going these days to let these things bother me anymore!
This is getting very annoying, here is the notice I keep getting.

Google Play Service runs as a system service and will take location updates when any dependent apps (i.e. Chrome, Play Store) require location.
From the message above, it looks like it might be related to the Android Device Manager. Have you tried removing your Google account from the device?
This might reduce these popups or random GPS points that you are experiencing.
Yea, based on location services usage it appears to be Google Play. But I'm not ready to wipe and reload, at least not yet.

Google Play Services does not show that Location is an App Permission, but the "Google App" has an App Permission of Location and it's on. But it gives you a warning that things may stop working if you turn off Location for the App.

Here is a strange turn, I took an extended trip out of state, and the phone stopped doing the constant annoying activity (at least for now). Will keep my fingers crossed that it's over with, but can't explain why traveling a ways from my "home" area would stop the activity.

replies.text: What's that old quote? "Our's is not to question why..." or something like that - weird! Hope it stays that way for you! Looking forward to seeing (just want to see it, honest) the new S8 Active... hope it's soon!

thread.text: Well, I caught the Location Services back on again today, and the culprit seems to continue being Google Play Services. Thankfully none of the nagging messages are back, yet.

Hi,
I came across this thread because I also noticed some unusual location requests from Google Play Services. I think this Register article gives an explanation.
Guess I'll be leaving my GPS off from now on...
Well, that proves what I've experienced. Apple is looking better and better.

thread.text: Hey guys. I found this thread while researching the same thing, and I may have found something that could help. As I was digging around in my location menu, under Improve Accuracy, I had Scan for Wifi and Scan for Bluetooth still checked, and it seemed like every time I was getting the icon, I was in a place where my phone was scanning for those things. title: can my galaxy s7 active be rooted/network unlocked

thread.text: im actually trying to figure out why my camera stopped working but gives me a message saying that its in use. i have takeing it to a couple of locale repair places but want non of them touch. they say its because once they open it,its no longer water proof. im not worried about that

S7 should still be under warranty I should think..?
Rooting and network unlocking are vastly different and neither will fix your camera issues I reckon. 
Dial *#0*# which gets you into the service menu. You can test the hardware there. If it fails, take it to Samsung to fix. If not, then you have some software glitch.
First step I'd try is open settings... Camera... 
Force stop the app, clear its cache and data. Reboot the app and see if it works. If not, try a cache partition wipe of the device. This usually fixes minor bugs. If this all fails, join the forums and we'll talk you through some more stuff you can try.... 
Good luck!

title: Galaxy S7 Active - Screen Cracked - No Impact! In my pocket!

thread.text:
Hello all, 
I'm new to this forum, but a veteran when it comes to the internets and technology. I recently purchased the GS7 Active specifically to avoid worrying about damaging the device/water issues. As we all know, the water tests have recently been showing some very concerning results. More concerning than the water-proofing issues is what happened to my device last week. 
I took my phone out of my pocket and noticed what I originally though was a scratch... perhaps a hair? My brain wasn't even processing the possiblity that the middle of the screen randomly cracked for no reason. After trying to blow away the hair/wipe off the scratch/smudge I quickly realized that the impossible situation is very possible. 
I have a crack right through the top center of the screen in my brand new GS7 Active! Are you kidding me?! It's a very strange crack too, curved in the center with small perendicular cracks along the larger crack. 
I've owned a GS2, 3, 4, and 5... skipped the 6 and went for a GS7 Active. In every previous Galaxy I've owned I have never once damaged the device. I've dropped a few in my day. But never would I assume the GS7 Active would simply crack in my pocket!!! 
Worst than this, there are other reports of this happening the same exact way on the Samsung forums.

I won't mention the exact details, but I will continue to recommend Samsung products. I would recommend dealing with Samsung on this one. I think they have a problem with the S7 Active LCD/Digitizer/Outer Glass unit. Hopefully, this is an issue limited to the early adopters and not a design flaw in the product itself.

All they did is waste my time. As the retailer who sold me my phone, they should have at least investigated my claims. I'm an ***** (why is toidi <- backwards, censored, lol) and never took any photos, but I can describe it. My crack originated from the back button and stretched probably 3/4 the way to the edge of the screen. The initial crack looked just like a christmas tree high density, white, fine cracks forming from the back button and becoming fewer as you move to the edge of the phone. From there a few long cracks splintered, just as you would expect glass to, from that initial crack then around the center of the screen and some at the bottom of the screen under the buttons.
I hope my experience helps someone else, and as GSCMont pointed out, might become extra data used to indicate a real problem Samsung might have on their hands. I will come back to this thread and answer any questions anyone else might have... Good luck everyone! Don't back down, but be polite!

The same thing just happened to me I pulled out my phone from my pocket and it's scratched from my keys I had no idea this would be possible on an S7 active. I should have stuck with my pristine iPhone but I switched to the active for the ruggedness what a mistake now I'm stuck for the next two years with a scratched phone.
What's ironic is I have a screen protector on order I thought the phone could handle a day or two without one

There is a video on YouTube by JerryRigEverything in believe who torture tests the S7 Active. In the video he showed the screen can easily be scratched with a pen or keys because of the plastic protector. I believe if you could remove the plastic film, the glass underneath would be more scratch resistant.

if they are scratches you should be able to feel them by lightly dragging a fingernail across them; if its a crack below, you shouldnt feel anything, and in direct glare it should appear seamless as you pan the screen through the glare of a light or the sun. alternately use a playing card, again lightly dragging across the fault, and watch for drag or a snap; that would indicate a scratch rather than a crack.
thats an odd and tough place for a crack to appear; they tend to prefer edges or to make their way to an edge; has the fault/crack expanded? usually they get worse as the tempered glass (which is under stress by nature of being tempered) relieves its tension by expression of increased cracks, with no outside additional force needed.

My guess is that Samsung will not warranty this, because they are scratches, and not a defect in the device. It would "appear" to me, that something was apparently in your pocket at the time it occurred. With the new plastic coating they are using, it scratches much easier, that's why I put a tempered glass protector ontop of the screen.
If it were me, I would not fault Samsung on this particular issue, because I knew it was easier to scratch, due to the plastic coating, as I did much research on the device, before purchasing. Good luck with your endeavor, I would think it wouldn't be too expensive to replace the plastic coating, through Samsung, if they chose to charge you.
Chris

thread.text:
Posting a pic is easy. 
1 - Click the Insert Image button...
2 It will open this window ...
3. Click the From Computer tab in that window, then click Browse to select your picture from your hard drive.
4. Last click the Uploads Files(s) text... wait a few seconds and you will see something like ...ATTACH=CONFIG SomeNumber ATTACH with some additional characters added to your text.
That's it, post and you will see your pick.

title: Using AT&T Galaxy S7 Active on T-Mobile Disables Cellular Data

thread.text: I purchased an AT&T Galaxy S7 Active phone to be used on T-Mobile network. The phone works and operates great until I change mobile carrier type from AT&T to T-Mobile. With T-Mobile carrier Type settings in place and the phone powered off. When customer powers on the phone, the cellular data remains disabled. The ONLY way to enable cellular data is to enable then disable the Airplane mode (toggle airplane mode). We went through several phone calls with T-Mobile and Samsung support doing cache resets and factory restore, but nothing worked. So, Samsung finally agreed to check the phone out under warranty. Unfortunately, Samsung repair personnel down in Texas did not repair or correct the problem. The repair personnel simply followed a maintenance guide that only test and checks the phone’s "core" functionality. The repair technician should have tested and checked “user” functionality such as what is affected after changing carrier types – the well documented problem I was experiencing. Perhaps Samsung knows about this issue, and simply went through formal process to show effort only to ignore this issue. I feel this is a firmware issue that should be corrected by Samsung.

title: Would you buy an S7 Active today?

thread.text:

replies.text:
The S7 Active or even the S6 Active, are the type of devices which i would happily pick up 1 - 2 years after launch. The reason i say that is because of the specs inside. When they launch, it has the best available and that will keep anyone going for a while. Obviously the standout feature it how rugged they are but also that they have a really large battery. I mean 4,000 mAh is HUGE. 
So yes, i would definitely recommend it if you are an outdoor type of person. You can always put a bulky case on your iPhone but its just not the same haha.
EDIT:I see you got the S7, Thats awesome!

Holy moley that is such an old phone. I used to have the HTC Inspire too back in the day, that phone was awesome (screen was considered HUGE). I'm a former owner of BOTH the S6 Active and S7 Active. I can tell you the pros and cons of both:
S6 Active:
+ Great 16MP Camera
+ Slimmer than the S7 Active
+ Still has the IR blaster
+ Good 3500mAh battery
+ Probably cheaper in price by 50% or more
+ Samsung Pay
- No microSD slot
- Plastic & rubberized plastic body (scuffs will be more visible)
- Design looks a little weird
S7 Active:
+ Fingerprint scanner
+ Better build quality (hybrid of metal and rubberized plastic)
+ Much bigger 4000mAh battery
+ microSD slot is back
+ Shatter-resistant screen (rated most rugged smartphone)
+ Samsung Pay
+ Dual Pixel camera for instant focusing and low light photos
- NO IR Blaster
- Screen has a layer of plastic on top making it easier to scratch
- Phone is a lot thicker than the S6 Active
- There was an issue with the first batch of S7 Actives that failed water tests (phones manufactured sometime in June-July)
- 12MP camera loses detail compared to the 16MP of the S6 Active
- Probably costs a lot more
I personally recommend the S7 Active due to the upgrades but it's up to you and if you're willing to spend a bit more.

thread.text: I would most definitely get the S7 Active today. Especially over the S6 Active. The S7 Active has a real water damage replacement policy for one. So for the last few days my S7 active has been running poorly. Freezing up, extremely slow, poor battery, etc. 
Anybody else experiencing this?
I refuse to do a factory reset. I have personalized and saved so much.
I have cleaned cache and restarted several times. 
I do notice my signal has been horrible. Specifically where I work.
Could a bad signal cause the phone to be running to poorly?
Also location services keep turning on.
UGH!!!
Poor signals shouldn't cause the phone to run poorly. I think you are left with only one alternative; the reset.
Part of the problem may be continually clearing the cache. That means it has to re-save all that stuff.

I should amend my post that the poor battery life may be partially due to a bad signal. But the freezing, and running slow won't be. I still stand by my suggestion of a reset.
@Aquila may be right, but it would also depend on how often the cache is cleared.

It's quite difficult to know for sure what's causing those problems, but you could try a couple of things. 
If you're using an SD card unmount it temporarily and see what happens.
See in your battery stats which apps/processes are using a higher percentage. Maybe there's an app running wild in the background.
I agree with Aquila and Golfdriver97, clearing cache frequently won't help at all and a very bad signal is a sure cause for a battery drain.

title: A year with my S7 Active and thoughts on my next phone

thread.text:
I've had my ups and downs with this phone. But by and large, I've really enjoyed it. I even invested in 3 wireless fast chargers b/c I'm pretty sure my next phone will be a Samsung. My only problem is...which one. I'm worried that Samsung is de-activfying the next Active. I don't like the loss of physical buttons and the so-far lack of Active button-specific software features. 
Finally, I'm starting to really have second thoughts about the concept of the "built-in" ruggedness of the phone. I'm normally desk-bound all day but had the need to spend the last three days outside in the summer heat, doing demanding work all day long. In that short time, my Active has had a few spots worn through the outer painted layer of the "case" and now has ugly, white-ish rubber/plastic exposed. If I had a regular galaxy in a regular case, the case would take the abuse and could be swapped out if I didn't like the look. But since the phone itself has absorbed the damage, I have no such option. Has anyone else been bothered by this? I'm thinking I'd rather get an S8+ or Note 8 and just slap a case on them.

thread.text:
Greetings all, 
I am new here, and mostly a newb when it comes to Android. I am blind so I use my S7 active with text to speech and the voice assistant on. This may seem minor to most of you, but for someone like myself who uses it all day... the Stock voices are Timmy and seriously annoying. 
When I first set up my S6 Edge, I received a prompt to download a file called:
SamsungTTS HD US English
The "TTS" in the name indicated to me that it was a voice file, so I told the prompt yes. After the file had completed downloading, the voice on my phone change to a very acceptable voice that was easy to listen to. It also offered accurate pronunciation of letters as I was typing.
That prompt never came up on this S7. I looked through the Play Store, the Amazon App area, and the Galaxy apps app on my phone.. With no luck. So I am now stuck with the stock voices, and it's threatening to take my sanity. Can anyone out there direct me to any enhance or high-quality voices for the Samsung or Google Text-to-Speech engine? I cannot even find the Ivona HQ app for those voices.
Thank you in advance for your assistance and may God bless!

replies.text:
Hello BlindSurvivor - this is the first chance that I've had to actually sit down with my phone and look into settings and see if I could help. I went to Settings, then Personal, then Accessibility, clicked on Vision and then just scrolled down to Text-to-Speech and clicked on it. For some reason, Google Text-to-Speech was already selected on my phone and I don't remember doing that myself (of course I'm 66 years old - I could have!) When I clicked the settings gear icon for Google Text-to-Speech, I got Language, Settings for Google Text-to-Speech and Install voice data. Language was obvious, Settings was pretty standard stuff that didn't need any changes but Install Voice Data brought me to a list of countries where I scrolled down to English (United States) and clicked that, which opened "Voice set 1 - 10 MB which I clicked this opened up a list of seven voices, all of which sounded very nice - loud, but very nice. Three males and four females.
The Samsung Text-to-Speech gives you a couple of choice but I found no way to listen to the sound of the voices... that may be what you are running and having the issue with. I hope my instructions aren't too complex for you to find your way through. Let me know if there's a better way I could explain it for you and I'll try to re-word it or even turn it into a numbered list of steps maybe? Good luck
Jim D

Wiped cache (always do) after install.
How do you wipe cache? Will i lose any data?

No you will not lose anything.
Turn phone off. Give it a minute. Hold down home button, volume up button and then power button all at the same time.
You will see little blue text in the top of the screen. Menu appears, use volume down key to go to wipe cache partition, then use power button to select. after cache is wiped, reboot system. Just be careful to look at what you are selecting as there are options in that menu for master reset which I do not believe you are interested in.

title: Initial boot & set-up of unlocked S7A... after receiving thru post/mail/UPS, etc?

thread.text:
Hello-- Thanks very much for any & all replies. 
For unlocked S7A, do I just.... well, what do I do first? 
Install my micro SIM & microSD.... then boot up.... then restore backed-up data?

That should be all you need to do (assuming the phone supports your carrier's networks bands). When prompted during the setup process, enter your Google account and password. It should ask you if you want to restore using settings and data from a previous device, or if you want to set it up as a completely new device.

Thank you very much, B Diddy ! I backed-up my current S7A last night (on my laptop PC) using the Samsung app Smart Switch; it said the back-up was successful. I haven't backed-up anything on Google Cloud (or google drive?) however. Would you suggest I also do a Google Drive back-up? Never done one, but willing to try. Thanks again!

There's no discrete "back up entire phone to Google Drive" option. If you go to Settings>Backup & Restore and have backup turned on and set to your Google account, then your phone's settings and some app data (but not all) will be backed up, so it's not a bad idea (and it was probably on by default anyway). The apps that do backup data to your Google account depend on the developer. You can go to your Google Dashboard on the web (google.com/settings/dashboard) and click on the Android heading to see a list of apps that do backup data and/or settings to your Google account.

Thanks again for the info B.Diddy. I will do as you suggest, (although my un-intuitive so-called auto-replace Samsung keyboard just tried to say: 'I will so as you digest' ;)
Sorry for delay in replying; this last week has been a bit hectic as my notebook motherboard-to-video card coprocessor connection burned/or I guess finally cooked-out last Thursday, the 23rd, (although after 10 years of constant business use). So, a few hours after backing up with Smart Switch to PC, I lost the computer !:(
Then new S7A arrived Friday afternoon, so I downld'd Smart Switch to the (AT&T store S7A) I had decided to return and took both to local AT&T store. Didn't have to use SS though, as they used their quicker data transfer machine. 
They did charge $45 for re-stock, but offered same insurance for the Amazon unlocked S7A, which came loaded with 6.0 (instead of 7.0 like store S7A).
At first I was bummed....but by Sunday had decided I like Marshmellow better than Nougat. 
So that's it. New (amazon) S7A running same/as well as (store returned) S7A. Thanks again! ;)
Now I'm wondering about the 2016 S7A recall. How to determine if an S7A is a: pre-recall, or post-recall S7A?
Update: Found date of manufacture + all other info re phone on 'Samsung Info app'

. . . . Update - Part Two:
Ehem, okay, after downld'ing and using the 'Samsung Info app'.... it turns out that the pristine, perfectly good AT&T store bought S7A (that I really liked)---but returned (on the 14th day) last Friday---was manufactured in May 2017. 
And the S7A (advertised as 'unlocked') I ordered (thru Amaz last Wed) and activated on Friday the 23rd, was manufactured on 18 Aug 2016, ten months ago ! :~\
Hmm, well at least it was after the mid July 2016 Samsung (water damage issue was apparently resolved or fixed/updated) re: S7A's shipped before or after mid July 2016.
Still, it's a little close for comfort. 
So you may ask yourselves, as I am asking myself, Why..........would you/I do that? :~\
Answer: no contract; unlocked; no tax; no shipping; almost $300 less than AT&T store S7A.
Cons: a 9 month older phone w/ older battery. :(
Nevertheless I'm hoping for no regrets. Hoping . . . . .

title: Open legal draft to Samsung regarding S7 Active water damage faults (ALL Active users please read)

thread.text:
Hey everyone, in light of recent events, ie Samsung fully acknowledging there were production flaws with their S7 Active devices by their own admission, my GF (trial/litigation attorney) and myself (studied law/never took the bar exam, and work in film/photog/'legalese' of advertising) are putting together an open letter/request to Samsung to do one, or more, of the following...
1) Test, diagnose, repair or replace as necessary, any devices deemed to be flawed, in a timely fashion with consideration for recompense to affected owners/users, as well as acknowledge the manufacturing process defect, in a timely (expedited) fashion, with full reimbursement of any and all fees associated with shipping as well as reasonable recompense to affected users, in the event a recall is not initiated.
2) Further warranty said affected, defective, returned-for-service/warranty devices, fully for 1 (one) year from date of receipt of repaired/replaced device by manufacturer or manufacturer approved repair facility, for water incursion up to and including IP68 specifications, assuming device condition is within 'reasonable and acceptable usage guidelines' (ie not banged up, not cracked/compromised, as in visible abuse or damage to - glass, plastic, rubber, seals, and ports) upon receipt by manufacturer or manufacturer approved repair facility, in the event a recall is not initiated.
3) Replace said device (assuming device meets above 'reasonable usage' specifications and guidelines and has not been clearly abused), within current warranty period with NO extension beyond current 1 (one) year warranty period, with a device that has been verified to have undergone the new 'corrected' assembly methods, in the event a recall is not initiated.
4) recompense current S7 Active owners whom have had unfortunate issues with their devices fairly, and in a timely fashion, as well as expedite shipping for affected 'launch' and current stock of devices, or expedite their replacement with new units that have been assembled with 'new' assembly methods, acknowledging, by Serial Number, IMEI/HEX ID, or other means, the devices' compliance with current, 'corrected' assembly methods, maintaining current 1 (one) year warranty period, in the event a recall is not initiated.
5) Recompense/reimburse, or refund affected users for any and all incurred shipping costs, 'down time' due to defects within reason, in the event a recall is not issued.
6) Recall affected devices, and either
______A) Compensate users for 'down time' without device while expediting repair/replacement at manufacturers expense, OR
______B) Offer a replacement device, which has been built to new 'compliant specification' as stated by Samsung, shipped out (first) wherein affected user then returns flawed device in a manufacturer/carrier supplied shipping format, within the current 1 (one) year warranty period.
Any suggestions, questions, etc please post below. I will ask that you contact myself at a later date once the letter has been formally drafted and readied. We, as owners/users, no longer have the onus and burden of proof to prove there is an issue, however we must allow and provide the manufacturer fair means and time to fix/repair/replace/recall the devices. Affected users, please keep any and all communications (including links to posts you and others have made in this regard (NOT speculation, but verified issues ONLY) on this and other forums, with Samsung, other users, etc) for your records. Again this is a rough draft; please bear with us here.
SHOULD you decide to test your device for flaws, by all means PLEASE record it, in ONE SHOT, where the device is totally visible when doing so, that there may be absolutely NO question as to your testing methodology. I do NOT recommend testing these devices at this time, even to their specified ratings, but if you must, feel free to contact me for tips or suggestions on how to do so that you have the burden of proof CLEARLY on your side. BY ALL MEANS PM ME FIRST IF YOU PLAN TO TEST YOUR DEVICE, and i will guide you through it clearly and concisely so as to best maintain your warranty and accurately test your device (far more scientifically than Consumer Reports). Though i express no guarantees or warranty of compliance, i will go out of my way to ensure any testing you do will meet IP68 guidelines and stay within IP68 ratings to the best of my abilities within reason and means of consumer to consumer 'over the web' means, and that your results would be recorded accurately and reliably, to the best of my abilities and with respect to your compliance of my guidelines.
To be perfectly clear, we are NOT seeking compensation in any manner, simply full rectification and correction of this issue with Samsung. Should you decide to pursue legal action on your own, it is recommended to find an attorney in your state as we are not pursuing legal action at this time, nor will we do so on behalf of others.
If you know of any other S7 Active owners with water issues, please direct them to this site and this post, so that we may aggregate as much data as possible.
Thank you for your time, please post a response below to show interest.
-Slade8525

replies.text: I haven't had a problem with mine S7a but I also haven't had it in water. I use it to much for work to be without a phone.

thread.text: I'm in. No damage yet even though I've had the phone in pools and a Waterpark but I agree with what you're doing.

I plan on using it as I would normally use a smart phone device. I currently don't know if it meets IP68. It should not be expecting to much to get what you paid for.

I don't understand all the hesitation about going after Samsung on this. I bought my S7 Active specifically to have a TOUGH, WATER RESISTANT phone! Samsung has admitted a flaw that compromises what they and AT&T repeat ad nauseam in every advertisement for the phone. It's like advertising a parachute that doesn't work when jumping from airplanes then stating "Oh, we don't expect too many complaints." And the sad thing is, they are right! Just like people don't like to mail in rebates, they don't like to return things like this because A.) they are afraid it's actually their fault, B.) They don't want the down time and C.) They're lazy. Samsung knows that the harder they make it, the less they end up losing. replies.text: LOL, even if yours is completely waterproof after testing it at it's limits? I don't understand this. What phone would you go to then?

I'm not going to go drop it in my pool and have it pass, giving me a false sense of security or have it fail and have to fight with att/samsung

More power to you. Mine has passed the test this summer vacation (as deep as I care to personally be in a pool and at a Waterpark with no damge) but I can see how that would not be to everyone's satisfaction. The question remains though as to which device would be a viable alternative. I for one cannot think of one or else I would have considered it when making my purchase decision. My main requirements were ruggedness (water and drop), top tier processor and memory, massive battery, and SD card slot for GSM networks.
That's why I want to pursue the course of action the OP has set out to do. I want this unique device to be backed up 100% by Samsung since nowhere else can I find another device that suits my needs so closely.

Oh I don't want anything else. I would want another Galaxy Active. I've owned 4 iPhones and this is my second Galaxy Active. I bought the first one (the original S4 Active) after my iPhone's 4s's internals rusted out from 2 years of running with it averaging at least 60 miles a week. Lots of sweat. The S4 Active was great but the fact that it relied on little rubber flaps for its water resistance always made me nervous. My wife got and had buyer's remorse over an iPhone 6 Plus so 2 weeks later, it was mine. I put it in a Lifeproof and away I went.
I didn't think I'd ever go back to Android but we went on a cruise in June and halfway through, I got some water in the 6 Plus and switched over to a new Active. I also got the Gear S2 Classic watch from AT&T for $50 as part of the deal. So I definitely want to stay with Samsung. 
But what I've lost now is the peace of mind I thought I'd paid for by switching to a phone that meets the IP68 standard. Heck I could have filed an insurance claim on my iPhone but that didn't give me any guarantee the same thing wouldn't happen again. 
So don't take my position as an anti-Samsung rant. I like them. I'm waaaay more impressed with this phone than I ever was with my S4 Active. I'll gladly buy another "fixed" Active if they gave me the choice tomorrow. If not, I'd go to an edge or regular S7 and put them in a case.

And remember, until all this kerfuffle with Consumer Reports and CNET, Samsung wasn't even actually guaranteeing the phone for water damage.

The phone is covered, you just do not like the terms. Anyways, good luck to you. I am going to be posting about what I love about my S7 Active and live with no fear! lol!

AT&T is honoring almost any water damage related issues with the S7 Active, including insurance reversals. Anyways)

1 year manufacturer warranty carries over to new, fixed device as well. I just had to get passed the frontline customer service person and talk to retention. hey not at all; any info as far as we are concerned is ammo for the fight.
were not finished with this, we just got confirmation a few times it was no hassle/no questions (assuming it wasnt damaged ie dropped severely etc), and had 2 confirmed replacements pass a rudimentary dunk test previous units failed. Phone Info (Samsung) states mid-august production dates, Korean build, and devices are listed as 'New', as per what Samsung told our friends.
Language probably wont change; their actions might however. they will likely NEVER recall this device to be honest, and i can understand why, even though i personally am an affected consumer. The real push is to get them all replaced with fixed new devices; then push for something else too.
I wish i could give you a more affirmative response, but at this time, thats all i have or all i can say. Its still a work in progress.
Again, both my GF and my own S7 Active have worked just fine after long duration underwater, as have some others, that were launch devices.
I know of one user, personally, who has gone kayaking and waded/swam for a good 20 minutes with the device in her pocket; it was a launch day purchase. My GF and i bought ours shortly after our camping/kayak trip with said user was over; its why we bought them; its what i expect out of our devices and your device as well; just what they advertised.
This, on top of the Note 7 issue, is REALLY turning me off to Samsung right now; mostly the downtime and wasted time to get a return initiated, AND the 'dead time' where the faulty device is shipped out, and a replacement has not yet arrived; thats the key part we are now engaged in negotiating; compensation for downtime/lost time/productivity/etc.
My time isn't free; even my consultations cost more than this phone. My GF's are even pricier. Your time is JUST as valuable; you purchased the device based on its advertised specs; it doesnt matter why or how it failed to live up to its advertised specs; its an acknowledged flaw, which causes grievance to the user, and that user should be compensated.

Has this gotten off the ground? Amy news?

I used to debate back and forth over which was better, Samsung or iPhone, based solely on the qualities of the handset. What this Active issue, the Note 7 debacle, and my experiences with my Gear S2 smartwatch have taught me is it goes beyond the phone itself. It's what Samsung does and does not take responsibility for after the sale. Their customer service is atrocious compared to Apple. During my most recent experience trying to complain about getting a very early production date Active as a warranty swap, at one point I was transferred to Samsung's customer service. I was greeted by a very testy person at the end of a bad, scratchy connection who acted like she had no idea any Samsung phone had ever had a problem. I couldn't take her for more than a minute and a half before telling her she obviously wasn't prepared to help me and bid her goodbye.
Being in a household with a wife and two teen girls that all have iPhones still, I had to make two separate calls to AT&T about issues with their phones in the past few weeks. AT&T tech support, realizing I was beyond their technical grasp, passed me off to Applecare's iPhone support line. between the two phones, I spent probably three and a half hours on the phone with them as they meticulously troubleshot the problems I was experiencing. I couldn't believe I was getting this for free. I kept waiting for them each time to just give me a set of further instructions to carry on by myself, letting them get off the line. But they never did. I think it speaks volumes for how the two companies have conducted themselves. As much as I love my Active, when it's time for a new phone (especially now that they are water resistant), I'm probably switching back to Apple again. 
Sorry for the rant, but I'm just tired of seeing this go in circles and get nowhere.

I've been told that the top layer on the s7 active is not replaceable, which sucks because it scratches and wears out really fast. However, according to samsungs website it is:Galaxy S7 active Screen Protector Replacement Kit
Can anyone confirm, because this fixes the one issue with this phone for me. Kit even comes with a tool to remove the top layer

I saw this on the Samsung website as well. Not sure if it is an actual screen replacement or screen protector? It would be great if it was a replacement poly carbonate screen replacement.
Edit: I looked at the instructions and it does look like a screen replacement?ET-FG891_Quick-Start-Guide-S7-active-replacemen-screen-layer-replacement_2.pdf

I called samsung and it looks like it's not yet available, but it seems they do intend on providing replacements and it's meant to be changed by the user. 
The kit includes a replacement top layer, a removal tool, a dust removal sticker, and a microfiber cloth.
I don't know what the cost will be. Motorola has a similar kit for their tough phone and it costs $30
I bet that most people with screen damage issues have a pristine glass screen under the protective layer. In the meantime if you could peel the top layer off without the tool you could just use an aftermarket screen protector, but I think it's the polycarbonate layer that provides the shatter resistance
that is simply a plastic or glass screen protector; NOT a replacement for your scratched polycarbonate screen; that layer is heat bonded to the glass. the top polycarb layer is NOT replaceable.

The pdf spec sheet shows you how to remove it. It's only viewable on the desktop version of the page. It's titled "screen layer replacement guide". Step 1 is how to remove old screen layer
http://www.samsung.com/us/system/consumer/accessory/et/fg/89/etfg891ctebus/ET-FG891_Quick-Start-Guide-S7-active-replacemen-screen-layer-replacement_2.pdf

I get it, and I'm happy about it. What I don't get is why is the phone pictured on the website so different than mine? The sensors that are on the left of the speaker at the top of the phone are on the right on in the picture, for example. Is the ATT variant that different? Also my S7A has a gap between the home button and the other two tactile buttons, but the picture shows a line and no gap.

replies.text:
Idk why the picture is wrong on the webpage The description also seems to be generic placeholder text for a screen protector, but the pdf instructions show the correct phone and more detail about the replacement
Samsung confirmed the part number for me, but no eta on availability or price yet

thread.text: did they confirm that the polycarb layer on the OEM screen IS REMOVABLE? it appears the item is just a screen protector, and the linked article referenced is simply their method to remove an old screen protector, NOT the OEM polycarb layer built on the phone as it exists 'out-of-box'.

replies.text:
It is removable. I was able to peel mine off at the top a little. It is much thinner then a normal screen protector. Which is probably why some people thought that you can't remove it. It is a thin polycarbonate sticker, you can't even tell it's there until it scratches and wears out from your thumbs
Just waiting for the replacements to be in stock. I wouldn't recommend trying to remove it with out the tool that comes in the kit, although I was able to lift the polycarbonate layer off at the top with a very small screwdriver
ill be d@mned.

I managed to peel my one off too using a square razor blade to pry it up in the corner. It took a few attempts to get it right. 
So pleased I came across this thread coz my screen got real scratched up in my pocket only a few days after purchasing. Thought i was gonna have to live with this nasty *** scratch for good. 
Now I'm just waiting for the polycarb replacement screen from samsung, i will put a gorilla glass screen on top once installed.

Still waiting for them to be available last time I called... 
But ya, im sure most complaints about messed up screens could probably be fixed by just removing the factory screen protector cause it's soft and sometimes the adhesion messes up too.
If I use an aftermarket protector, I'd rather take the polycarb one off first because part of the design to protect the screen is that it's recessed slightly below the rubber lip. And I don't like the idea of putting a screen protector on top of a screen protector.

The thing is that the polycarbonate one offers much more shatter protection than the aftermarket screen protectors. You can't really even tell it's on there so most of use who are putting on a glass protector are doing it mainly to prevent scratches on the protective shield. With that shield the Active survives extreme drops as mentioned on these forums.

replies.text: How do you activate it or where do you check to see if it's activated.

Activated automatically with Nougat. Dial *#0011# to get to service menu, if you are on a 3CA tower, and your phone is using constant data, you will see 3 sections of CA and it will tell the 3 bands being used and their bandwidths
Awesome Jeremy - Great Info... thank you!!!

thread.text: From what I am seeing my phone isn't using the 3CAA, is that correct since there are only two CAA listings?

replies.text:
You actually are using 3CA in that screenshot. I should have explained further. 
That menu shows your main band which is download and upload - you'll see - LTE RRC Conn band 30 at 10x10 
Then 2 more carriers / bands are aggregated to your main band 30 to add to your download 
CA add s1 - band 2 with a bandwidth of 10 mghz
And then another carrier, your third, added - 
CA add s2 - band 12 with a bandwidth of 10 mghz
You have a total of 30 mghz of download between the three, and since upload can't be aggregated at this time, you have 10 mghz of upload from your main carrier band 30
Granted the bands and positions will change, sometimes you'll get 3CA, sometimes 2CA, sometimes no aggregation

title: At&t unlocked for use on T-Mobile glitching

thread.text:
Right away after putting in the sim card the phone operated perfect. Little less than a week later it stopped connecting to the network. Could only call and text. One weird thing is hot-spot internet worked.

Any help will be appreciated.

Hi BryanH79!
Great choice on phone, super jealous! It's on my bucket list of devices. First, is the device fully paid off/unlocked, or are there still remaining payments on the AT&T account?
Second, have you tried adjusting the APN settings of the device when you have the T-Mobile sim in?
To change APN settings on a galaxy:
Settings > Mobile Networks > Access Point Names > Is T-Mobile showing up here? Does it match the same information i'm posting below? > You can hit the "add" button to set up a fresh APN setting. The settings should be set up in the following manner:
Name: T-Mobile US LTE
APN: fast.t-mobile.com
Proxy: <Not set>
Port: <Not set>
Username: <Not set>
Password: <Not set>
Server: <Not set>
MMSC: http://mms.msg.eng.t-mobile.com/mms/wapenc
MMS proxy: <Not set>
MMS port: <Not set>
MMS protocol: WAP 2.0
MCC: 310
MNC: 260
Authentication type: <Not set>
APN type: <Not set> OR Internet+MMS
APN protocol: IPv4/IPv6
APN roaming protocol: IPv4
Enable/disable APN: <greyed out unless there are multiple APN's>
Bearer: Unspecified

title: Silencing Incoming Notifications (Phone, Text, etc) - S7 Active

thread.text:
Hey guys, I've searched Google, here, and several other forums trying to find the answer for this and I'm not having any luck.............
I moved into my S7 Active back in January from an iPhone 6 Plus. I'd been using the 6 Plus for nearly 2 years so of course there was a little "learning curve" coming back to Android as well as retraining my muscle memory when it came to moving around on the screen and in menus, but I really like the phone & especially so since we recently got the update to Android Nougat.
One of the things I miss from my iPhone is that when I received a notification whether it was a phone call, text, whatever, I could just reach down and hit the volume up or down to silence it while it was in the holster on my belt. On my S7 Active it seems that isn't a luxury it has so it's a little frustrating. Even my Note 3 I had before the 6+ could do that. Where it comes in handy is when I'm on duty (public safety) and the phone goes off I could just reach down and silence it without pulling it out.
I have tried and tried with the Active to make that happen and I'm not getting anywhere. I've even gone page by page through the menus and settings and no luck. So I'm reaching out to the collective brain trust here to see if I'm missing something or if there's another way to make this work.
Please accept my thanks in advance for any help you guys can provide!!
It's late... I'll look into it tomorrow but I can't think of anything off the top of my head!
The only way I see to make it work is to either have DND or Mute on while on duty.

replies.text: Agreed, I just went through the manual and the only way to mute the ringer once it starts is to cover the screen or turn the phone face down on a table or desk. That obviously can't work if it's in your holster case so best bet is to put it in vibrate mode or DND/Mute, like 'TwitchPuppy' stated...

thread.text:
Thanks for the responses everyone. Unfortunately putting it on DND or Mute while on duty isn't an option because of an app we use called Active911 when being dispatched to a call that alerts us with the address, cross streets, and other pertinent call info, and as a compliment to that we also get an SMS/text message from our 911 center with the call address, etc. AND (lol), we use our phones for mobile CAD and receive messages that way also. I've tried putting it on vibrate but when it's in the OtterBox and in the holster on my duty belt you never feel it go off. The biggest thing is when I can't get to it right away to pull it out of my holster because of being hands on, or if I've got someone else's body fluids on me I don't want that transferring to my phone. To much s**t going around these days for all that LOL.
I'll keep exploring options. Thanks again for the help and suggestions!!!
*****EDIT******
WAIT lol............ I misunderstood how DND works. I thought it blocked out everything, I didn't realize you could pick and choose. I'll investigate this option a little more.

No, there seems to be an issue with your build! The update file is to go from G891AUCS2APL1 to G891AUCU2BPL4 which is Nougat. You can't just try to load that file on yours... it's expecting to see G891AUCS2APL1, not G891AUCS2AQA1! We're still kind of waiting for an answer as to what to do. It looks like you may have to use ODIN to Flash back to an earlier version of an AT&T OS and them come up to G891AUCS2APL1. Then you can load the Nougat update file. It's been a long time since I used the ODIN method but there's some pretty good instructions over on XDA Developers site that will walk you through it if you really want to go that way! https://forum.xda-developers.com/s7-...-root-t3473649

replies.text:
O.K., got it... if you really want to go through all this:
Go here:https://forum.xda-developers.com/s7-...-root-t3473649
scroll to "To Unroot, Click Below" then click "Link to Instructions Provided By (jembot)"https://forum.xda-developers.com/sho...&postcount=561
You are not unrooting, you are just using ODIN to bring the phone back to API2 which is a start. From there, you can then do the SD Card/Stock Recovery thing and use dogmatism's files to go "G891AUCS2API2 -> G891AUCU2APK2" > "G891AUCU2APK2 -> G891AUCS2APL1" > "G891AUCS2APL1 -> G891AUCU2BPL4" Nougat!

thread.text: Well Happy Birthday to me, just got the Nougat update on my active last night finished the install this morning, all seems well so far.

I for one am a fan of it. Totally customizable and I like the look.
I notice a battery usage difference too, for the better.
I am happy.

Tada... took five hours to go from illegal Nougat back to an old version of Marshmallow then all the way back to the latest version of Marshmallow then get the Update then get my Restore from the Samsung Cloud... but TADA!

Got it! I had seen the update and put it off b/c I was always busy when the prompt would pop up. Finally gave in and downloaded it before bed. It turned off my alarm! At any rate, I don't like the small font size. Gotta change that. Love the little optimizer function. Battery life seems a little better so far. Thought I was in power saving mode it was running down so slow. But I wasn't. I like how it gives you options to customize power saving mode. Pretty nice. Now I'm going to have to go read up on what else is new/different.

replies.text: I had to go through hell to get back to Marshmallow, just to get the Legal OTA... but it was worth it... this version is like three or four Revs higher than what I was running and is sweet! Love it!

thread.text: Saw that. It does seem pretty snazzy. The stats in my battery life manager are amazing. Nothing is showing up as using much power. Facebook had been gobbling up like 20% lately. I DON'T like how it got rid of the hour markers at the bottom of the predicted useage graph. Otherwise...thumbs way up.

I totally agree. Love the new look, options, how customizable it is and how smooth it is.
Really "0" complaints so far. Definitely a noted battery change for the better.
Only issue I ran into was I turned off auto time/day set (In an effort to download software when it was made available) and forgot to turn back on after update so it kept throwing off certain apps and made my text messages nutty but all good now.

I'd say thank your lucky stars! If I had the option to NOT update my S7 again, I would refuse!!!
I have only had AT&T 7.0 for a couple of days and I am simply amazed at how they seem to change what is good and works into something cumbersome.:- I am sure there are other User Unfriendly functions that have changed, but here are the first two that I noticed.
1) Contacts: Used to be that you brought up a contact it would list all available numbers for this person or place. Not any more! Now you have to select Details to select the number you want to dial.
2) Blocking a caller requires similar type multi step. Again through Details to Block.
Stay Tuned - More to follow!
I must have mellowed with age... I noticed the Contacts thing too but it just rolled right by... didn't really bother me that much. When you get to be 67... "whatever" becomes a keyword!!!

Blocking a caller was always a multi-step process for me, unless I was doing something wrong? Oh, and in "medium" battery saver mode, I had 38% at 10:30 PM last night, after taking the phone off the charger at around 5 am. I didn't excessively use FB yesterday but did have it open on several occasions. Still never went above 3% in the usage manager. Not exceedingly great compared to what some of you folks get. But pretty good compared to my normal battery stats.
So far , Android 7 seems to be the best one released . Looking forward to the release for our S6 Active on our second line, sometime in the future.

This update has completely changed how I feel about my phone for the better! I'm finally getting the amazing battery life everyone else has. Facebook has gone from like 20% down to 3% consistently, regardless of heavy use. I'm no longer counting down the days (well...years, lol) until I get a new phone.

replies.text:
Really Happy for you... I know you went through a rough patch there with some odd, unexplainable crap going on with the battery life. Glad Nougat took care of it and that you're happy with it!!! 
EDIT: I should add, "Live Long and Prosper, bkrell"

thread.text: Hah! Thanks! Yeah, don't know why my apps didn't play happy with Marshmallow. But Nougat seems to have been the cure for whatever was ailing it.

Now I have to start the process of training it I guess and see how good it gets. Pretty cool... I'll see if I can find the link to the article if you're interested.

thread.text:
I got Nougat today. I had to go to the Samsung area at the local Best Buy to get the update, as expected.
Pleasantly surprised. The settings are much easier to access and find (as opposed to the endless side scrolling from before). I am sure this superior method was present on much older Androids I had, because it is familiar. But Samsung seems to have had the clunky side-scroller for a long time until now.
Clean Master? Wasn't that the name of some sort of pointless malware that ad-paid apps tried to force on everyone? AndroidPit identifies it as malware to get rid of completely:https://www.androidpit.com/android-a...ve-immediately
Now it is built in... *shrug*. But it seems to work better than other such things before, and instead of taking 15 minutes to find out what is taking up what in memory under Marshmallow, it takes about 20 seconds. 
My launcher is Nova, and I expected things to be pretty much destroyed by Nougat. Instead, my widgets were disabled, and the "dock" area was decimated. It didn't take long for me to fix this back, and this Nova Launcher repair is the sum total of me having to fix something after the Nougat update.
Now, I hope my S7 Active is ready to go another year, before I even start to consider a Pixel Second Gen, an iPhone (only if they make IOS as good as Android instead of crippled too much of the time), or even an LG.
What does getting Assistant have to do with getting Nougat? Did you try before and it didn't work?

Yeah, since the Nougat OTA, the correct version of Google Play Services was installed which makes it easier to get the "Assistant" App installed. You have to go to Play Store and ask to get on the Google Beta Program, then after about 10 or 15 minutes, the app updates from regular Google to Google Assistant! There's a couple of articles you can read on how to do it... just, you guessed it... Google it! "Google Assistant for all phones"

Well, sad to say....battery life has gone into the toilet.
After about a week of bliss, now it seems even worse than before. I know I've had a couple of facebook updates but that doesn't seem to be the culprit. Android OS is consistently the highest percentage of battery drain. With fairly low usage, I'm at 47% 11 hours after taking it off the charger. A week ago, I was still at least in the 60s at this point in the day. That's w/ medium powersaver on. I did re-enable the gear app and the s-health app because I found out there were some updates for my gear s2 watch I'm no longer using. But when I started suspecting they were the culprit, I disabled them. I've had two restarts since then and no change in battery life. So...who the heck knows? Oh well, fun while it lasted.

replies.text: Here's my results since removing from the charger Friday night at 11:15 PM and it stayed off the charger until Monday at 3:00 PM (Screenshot is from Sunday @ 1:53 PM) - Battery was at 23% NOTE: I must add - I am also running Greenify!Attachment 255127

thread.text: Well, that's depressing!

replies.text: Yeah, I truly don't understand... but again, I don't do near as much in a day as you do either. The phone sits a lot of the time... I tell you, Greenify has made a hell of a difference. It's a PITA sometimes because it turns things off sooner than you might wish but it also saves battery on things you might normally forget about, running in the background. All I had to do was tell it things I DIDN'T want it to shut off and then let it do it's thing - battery has been MUCH better since firing it up!

thread.text:
Hey guys, since the Nougat update i have had terrible battery life. I usually would get home at 6:00 with 50-60% battery left over with 2-3 hour screen on time. Now its around 20-30% with 1-2 hours screen on time . I have wiped the cache and i run around 1/3 brightness. The only thing different is the Nougat update. Anyone having the same issues?
Thanks
Welcome to the forums. How long have you had the update? Have you tried rebooting the device?

Quite the opposite - battery life has increased for almost everyone I've spoken with on this Forum and on XDA. You already Wiped Cache - that would have been my first guess. I'm not sure what the hayell could be going on there. Check your "New" "Device Maintenance" Tab in Settings and let it do it's thing... make sure it gets to 100%, then check the "Battery" Icon at the lower left - that will take you to another page that will give you some more data, then at the top, up beside the battery percentage, click "Battery Usage" - that might point you to a culprit!

I updated the day the update came out. It has been rebooted several times. I have used the device manager multiple times a day and it doesn't seem to help at all. I am also on the optimized performance mode. As of right now at 1:20, i have had the phone off the charger for 6h and 50 min. 58 Min screen on time, zero videos played about 15 minutes of spotify playing and i am at 55% left. I am not sure what is going on but it is not good. Thanks for the help guys. this is frustrating to say the least.

replies.text:
I use the "Mid" Battery Saving Mode and I really don't notice any Performance "hit" at all... usually shows (obviously not real life) around 56 hours left after coming off the charger, based on my usage over the last 7 days??? Accuracy - who knows?
55% left after what you listed does sound pretty sad... not sure what to say. Try "Mid" Battery Saving Mode - REALLY doesn't hurt anything - just give it a try.

thread.text:
Nice to finally see the embargo lifted on the S7 Active, Samsungs event came and went on Friday and I was wondering what happened to this phone 
Phil, first, thanks for taking the time to brief us on the S7A, I am still on a S3 (which, amazingly, still works great, a little slow but otherwise OK!) so looking forward to the massive battery on this phone which will really help with day to day work when I'm on the go.
How do you find the fit/finish of the S7A. I realize this is not a S7 Edge with a fancy metal backing, but do you find the buttons have a solid feel to them?
How did you find the finger print sensor, did it work the majority of the time you used it?
I realize updates for the Active series are always slower to come out then the regular S series, but the battery life (to me) trumps software updates. I am kind of at the point where I just need a phone 'to work'.
Thanks for the review,
Chris

replies.text:
It's a nice mix of rugged-esque without really being too rugged, I think. You definitely get the feeling that this thing will stand up to more abuse than other phones. But it's also not HUGE, ya know?
And the buttons — at least in early use — seem plenty solid.Worked fine. Though I think I've definitely decided that Samsung's fingerprint sensors aren't my favorite.

thread.text:
Got the S7 Active today, had to hit two AT&T stores to get a grey/black one but am in good shape (I've been without a new phone for four years, so it was time, coming from a S3). The S7 Active is a great phone, of course AT&T rep tried to sell me a case, a screen protector and DirecTV (lol) but I politely declined and got out of there in 20 minutes.
Overall feel of the phone is very nice, its slightly taller than my S3 from a top/bottom measurement, but I can definitely deal with that. The killer 4000mAH battery is really what sells the phone. 
The display that AT&T is using for the S7 Active at the ATT store is pretty cool - hit a button and a clear cube, with a S7 Active inside, fills up with water. Pretty slick way of advertising the S7 Active.
Just getting rid of the bloatware now. So far the S7 Active seems to be working with my old ATT Microcell, so that is nice (I know the S6s had issues). Whether or not it will work 100% of the time, we will see.
Also, for those of you that are a fan of the LED notification that all Galaxy's have had...this one at least has a blue one, not sure if its multi-color, kind of a moot point with the Always On screen notifications but still nice to have a second option.
Chris

replies.text: Can you post some pics?

thread.text: I went to look at them and they only had the grey in a case with water in it so I could not see the back. No others on display. I am leaning towards the grey but need to see it in person.

Just a couple of notes on these pics -
a) I have already customized the phone with Nova Launcher and a few other add-ons/widgets/etc. Don't take my home screen and expect it out of the box...
b) Found out the notification LED is in fact multi color, so you can use that in addition to the Always On screen which I think is cool. A casual glance at the phone in a meeting is always nice instead of picking up the phone and turning it on (and being rude).
c) Battery life is amazing, I mean it should be for a 4000mAH battery, but its awesome.
d) Would have like more 'grippy' sides, but I can deal. I really don't want to put a bumper around this phone, it just increases bulk. It's big enough as it is.
e) I know the Active series does not receive as many 'updates' as the regular S series, but for battery life and ruggedness alone, I'm willing to make this tradeoff.
f) ATT had a whole bunch of accessories on launch day - cases, screen protectors, etc. Kudos to ATT for having their act together, despite the fact I didn't buy any of it  (they sure did try to sell it though!)
EDIT: Sorry I have no idea why the forum rotated the pictures...

replies.text: Looks great! If you take the picture in landscape orientation versus a portrait orientation they should post in the correct orientation.

thread.text:
Glad your ATT store had their act together. Ours is always a chaotic mess & you have to wait in line to speak with anyone at anytime. 
They had one S7A on display, though was not a working unit. Saw people waiting for 20 minutes ahead of me & did not wait around. 
Went to Best Buy. They were waiting for a display unit, but had gold ones to sell. I did not want to open a box & irritate who was going to buy
it as not thinking I want the gold one. The Samsung girl knew her smart watches, but not much else. So unless my S3 dies a sudden death, think I'll wait to see if the price drops a little. The bogo promo does not work for me. 
Thanks for the update/review above & hope to see more as people get them.

replies.text:
I also came from the S3. Great phone and I have to say, with the extended battery kit from Samsung, it held its own weight over the years, it was really ahead of its time back four years ago. 
I think you will find the S7 to be very fast/responsive compared to the S3, of course apps and Web content has evolved over time which has slowed the S3 down a bit. You still have a nice phone though! 
Chris

thread.text:
I was out running errands after mountain biking and I stopped in and bought a gray one. It was the fastest experience I have ever had in an Att store. I told the sales rep, Paulina what I wanted, she brought it, I paid and she asked if I wanted her to activate it and I said nope, so she put it in a bag with my receipt and I was walking out in 4 minutes! Was gonna wait for a price drop but what the hey...
Will set it up later, gotta entertain my kids lol!
would you ever share how you set up your phone. Going to be new to launchers/widgets and looking to dive in. Like how yours is looking.

Sure, no problem at all. So I use Nova Launcher in order to setup the main screen - Nova allows you to set the Google Search bar to 'float' up top, and it also allows you all sorts of configurations for icon size/positioning.
I purchased Beautiful Widgets (Pro version) for the weather/clock you see below the Google Search bar. You can fully customize how that looks, there are literally hundreds of templates within that application for fonts, layout, etc.
Between those two things, you should be all set. I user Light Manager Pro on the app store to control the LED color for certain notifications, for me it's White for email, Green for txt/mms, Purple for Voicemail, Yellow for work email, etc. I'll see how this pans out with the Always on display, perhaps I'll use one over the other, I'm not 100% sure.
Any questions just ask, we are all here to share.
Chris

title: How do I reverse the last update on my Galaxy s7 active. I hate the way it looks and acts.

thread.text: Everything changed. Colors awful. Text changed. Hate it.

Mmmm there's a lot of that going round.. 
You can theme the device, Nova launcher is popular and seamless from 6.0.1 to 7. I also use stealth icons as the native ones are crapola. The whole UI looks like it was designed by kids as a school project. 
They took many good functions away (like having a say whether to update the software or not), they did give us some good things too so it's really an individual thing. 
You probably can roll it back to marshmallow, but you may want to take it to a Samsung shop or similar as it's not hard to brick devices once you start playing with software..

There's some handy reading and files over on this Forum that can get you back to Marshmallow if you must. https://forum.xda-developers.com/s7-...mware-t3540866
It's a bit of work but I've done it before - I was actually running a sideloaded version of Nougat before the actual AT&T version came out, so I had to go back to Marshmallow so that AT&T would send me their Official Version last week! Just read, read, read... then decide if your willing to try it!

I just purchased a refurbished S7 Active from Amazon. It's not a factory refurb, but it's a very high rated seller with lots of transaction. My concern is, if this phone has been taken apart to be repaired, how much do you think I can trust the waterproofing of this phone? 
I was going to buy a waterproof case for that extra level of protection, but no one makes a waterproof case for the active since it's already rated as such. I kayak quite often and this thing is going to be in contact with water quite often!

You should note that the device is described as water "resistant" as opposed to water "proof". Vastly different. 
Note also that warranty doesn't cover water immersion damage. 
There are many posts around with disappointed peeps who drowned their expensive devices....

replies.text: Tim is right - you see it all the time. The later Models, manufactured after (I think) June 2016, are supposed to be much better, but still not "proof". I saw a test video somewhere on Youtube where a guy actually was skipping the phone like a flat rock, over a salt marsh, three or four times and letting it sink like 12 or 14 inches each time. He then picked it up, stepped out of the salt marsh onto the beach, rinsed it in the waves and made a call! He never said what the phone DIDN'T do the next day, but I'm sure between the water AND the salt, that S7 Active was TOAST! You are better off getting a Water Proof, water tight Bag and keeping the phone in it while in the kayak!

title: My S7 Active constant rebooting after Nougat update

thread.text: Anyone know how to fix this to stop the rebooting error?
